official-title.#text: To provide for the authorization of border, maritime, and transportation security responsibilities and functions in the Department of Homeland Security and the establishment of United States Customs and Border Protection, and for other purposes.

attestation-date.#text: Passed the House of Representatives July 28, 2014.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection Authorization Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: United States Customs and Border Protection Authorization Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

header.#text: Establishment of United States Customs and Border Protection

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: is amended to read as follows:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Section 411 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002

header.#text: Establishment of United States Customs and Border Protection; Commissioner, Deputy Commissioner, and operational offices

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection

text.#text: There is established in the Department an agency to be known as

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (in this section referred to as the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection

text.#text: There shall be at the head of

quote.#tail: ), who shall be appointed by the President, by and with the advice and consent of the

header.#text: Commissioner of United States Customs and Border Protection

text.#text: The Commissioner shall—
ensure the interdiction of persons and goods illegally entering or exiting the United States;
facilitate and expedite the flow of legitimate travelers and trade;

detect, respond to, and interdict terrorists, drug smugglers and traffickers, human smugglers and traffickers, and other persons who may undermine the security of the United States, in cases in which such persons are entering, or have recently entered, the United States;
safeguard the borders of the United States to protect against the entry of dangerous goods;
oversee the functions of the Office of International Trade established under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: section 402 of the Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Security and Accountability for Every Port Act of 2006/s:402

text.#text: enforce and administer all customs laws of the United States, including the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement
United States Citizenship and Immigration Services

text.#text: enforce and administer all immigration laws, as such term is defined in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , as necessary for the inspection, processing, and admission of persons who seek to enter or depart the United States, and as necessary to ensure the detection, interdiction, removal, departure from the United States, short-term detention, and transfer of persons unlawfully entering, or who have recently unlawfully entered, the United States, in coordination with

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: paragraph (17) of section 101(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act

text.#text: develop and implement screening and targeting capabilities, including the screening, reviewing, identifying, and prioritizing of passengers and cargo across all international modes of transportation, both inbound and outbound;
enforce and administer the laws relating to agricultural import and entry inspection referred to in
in coordination with the Secretary, deploy technology to collect the data necessary for the Secretary to administer the biometric entry and exit data system pursuant to

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004/s:7208

enforce and administer—

header.#text: Sense of Congress regarding the Foreign Language Award Program

text.#text: Congress finds the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: officers and agents who are proficient in a foreign language.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection

text.#text: Congress established the Foreign Language Award Program (FLAP) to incentivize employees at United States ports of entry to utilize their foreign language skills on the job by providing a financial incentive for the use of the foreign language for at least ten percent of their duties after passage of competency tests. FLAP incentivizes the use of more than two dozen languages and has been instrumental in identifying and utilizing

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection

text.#text: In 1993, Congress provided for dedicated funding for this program by stipulating that certain fees collected by

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: benefits by being able to focus its border security efforts in a more effective manner.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection

text.#text: Through FLAP, foreign travelers are aided by having an officer at a port of entry who speaks their language, and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: officers and agents to attain and maintain competency in a foreign language, thereby improving the efficiency of operations for the functioning of
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ’s security mission, making the United States a more welcoming place when foreign travelers find officers can communicate in their language, and helping to expedite traveler processing to reduce wait times.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: United States Customs and Border Protection

text.#text: It is the sense of Congress that FLAP incentivizes

No additional funds are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this Act and the amendments made by this Act, and this Act and such amendments shall be carried out using amounts otherwise made available for such purposes.
